raw_mentions:
Here are the extracted sentences that meet the criteria:

* Affinities lower than this are generally no longer measurable with common methods such as ELISA and are therefore of secondary importance for practical applications, especially preferred are muteins which bind the desired ligand/target with an affinity of at least 10^6 M^−1, corresponding to a dissociation constant for the complex of 1 μM.
* The muteins of the invention are able to bind the desired ligand (target) with a detectable affinity, i.e. with an affinity constant of preferably at least 10^5 M^−1.
A binding constant of more than 10^6 M^−1 was determined for hemoglobin with one of the muteins described in the examples.

A value of 2.2 μM was determined as the dissociation constant for the complex of the mutein HbgA and hemoglobin. 
The concentration of HbgA and also of ApoD were determined by absorption at 280 nm using a calculated extinction coefficient of 54600 M<sup>−1 </sup>cm<sup>−1 </sup>and 34150 M<sup>−1 </sup>cm<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. 
The solution was diluted with HBS to a series of concentrations ranging from 10 μM to 0.5 μM, and surfactant P20 was added to a final concentration of 0.005%. 
For this purpose, ca. 5000 RU of myoglobin and BSA, respectively, were immobilized on a CM5 sensor chip as described above, except using 100 μg/ml solutions in 10 mM acetate pH 4.7.
